elements.content: By control of mixed ligands with particular coordination sites, three novel three-dimensional (3D) 4d−4f heterometallic coordination polymers, [Ln4(H2O)2Ag(1,3-bdc)4(inic)5]·nH2O (Ln = Nd (1), n = 0.25; Eu (2), n = 0; 1,3-H2bdc = 1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid and Hinic = isonicotinic acid) and [Nd(H2O)Ag(1,2-bdc)(inic)2] (3) (1,2-H2bdc = 1,2-benzenedicarboxylic acid), have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions and characterized by elemental analysis, IR, thermogravimetric (TG) analysis, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Compounds 1−3 crystallize in the monoclinic system, space group C2/c. Compounds 1 and 2 are isostructural and exhibit novel 3D coordination frameworks constructed from two-dimensional (2D) wavelike lanthanide carboxylate layers and Ag(inic)4 complexes. To the best of our knowledge, they represent the first examples of 3D 4d−4f heterometallic coordination frameworks, in which the transition metal complexes bond to a 3D lanthanide carboxylate supramolecular framework with nanometer-sized channels built up from 2D wavelike layers. Compound 3 possesses an unusual 3D framework based on linkage of neodymium−carboxylate chains and silver(I) centers by inic ligands. The difference between both kinds of frameworks can be ascribed to the geometry effect of benzenedicarboxylate. Furthermore, the luminescent properties of 2 were studied.

elements.content: The design and synthesis of lanthanide−transition metal heterometallic complexes have attracted increasing attention due to their potential applications in magnetism, catalysis, adsorption, and photochemical sensors, as well as their intriguing architectures and topologies. A universal strategy for constructing lanthanide−transition metal heterometallic complexes is to assemble mixed metal ions and ligands containing mixed-donor atoms. So far, a variety of heterometallic complexes have been reported; however, most of them are discrete. The assembly of extended structures with three-dimensional (3D) lanthanide−transition metal heterometallic coordination frameworks based on the principle of crystal engineering is currently a formidable task, owing to complicated factors, such as the choice of organic ligands, the variable and high coordination numbers with low stereochemical preference, and the competitive reaction between lanthanide and transition metal ions and the organic ligands. Among these factors, the selection or design of ligands containing appropriate coordination sites is crucial to construct heterometallic complexes. Up to now, several types of ligands, such as CN-, carbonyl, N(CN)2-, amino acids, and pyridinecarboxylate, have been used to construct lanthanide−transition metal heterometallic complexes. Furthermore, controlling the assembly of target compounds in three dimensions by selecting the organic ligands and metal ions with different chemical natures is still a challenge to chemists. Fortunately, the characteristics of lanthanide and transition metal ions with different affinity for donors provides a unique opportunity for discovery of unusual 3D heterometallic coordination frameworks with useful physical−chemical properties and intriguing structural features. As is well-known, the ligands containing O-donor atoms, such as benzenecarboxylate, relatively easily bond to lanthanide ions to form lanthanide carboxylate polymers. If the second linear ligands containing N- and O-donor atoms and soft transition metal ions, such as Ag(I) ion, having a strong tendency to coordinate nitrogen donor atoms, are introduced to link the lanthanide carboxylate subunits, 3D heterometallic coordination frameworks may be obtained through the recognition between two types of metal ions and two kinds of ligands. In other words, Ln−O bonds construct the lanthanide carboxylate subunit, while M−N (M = transition metal ions) bonds direct the 3D heterometallic coordination framework.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and synthesis of lanthanide-transition metal heterometallic complexes have attracted increasing attention due to their potential applications in magnetism, catalysis, adsorption, and photochemical sensors, as well as their intriguing architectures and topologies. A universal strategy for constructing lanthanide-transition metal heterometallic complexes is to assemble mixed metal ions and ligands containing mixed-donor atoms. So far, a variety of heterometallic complexes have been reported; however, most of them are discrete. The assembly of extended structures with three-dimensional (3D) lanthanide-transition metal heterometallic coordination frameworks based on the principle of crystal engineering is currently a formidable task, owing to complicated factors, such as the choice of organic ligands, the variable and high coordination numbers with low stereochemical preference, and the competitive reaction between lanthanide and transition metal ions and the organic ligands. Among these factors, the selection or design of ligands containing appropriate coordination sites is crucial to construct heterometallic complexes. Up to now, several types of ligands, such as CN-, carbonyl, N(CN)2-, amino acids, and pyridinecarboxylate, have been used to construct lanthanide-transition metal heterometallic complexes. Furthermore, controlling the assembly of target compounds in three dimensions by selecting the organic ligands and metal ions with different chemical natures is still a challenge to chemists. Fortunately, the characteristics of lanthanide and transition metal ions with different affinity for donors provides a unique opportunity for discovery of unusual 3D heterometallic coordination frameworks with useful physical-chemical properties and intriguing structural features. As is well-known, the ligands containing O-donor atoms, such as benzenecarboxylate, relatively easily bond to lanthanide ions to form lanthanide carboxylate polymers. If the second linear ligands containing N- and O-donor atoms and soft transition metal ions, such as Ag(I) ion, having a strong tendency to coordinate nitrogen donor atoms, are introduced to link the lanthanide carboxylate subunits, 3D heterometallic coordination frameworks may be obtained through the recognition between two types of metal ions and two kinds of ligands. In other words, Ln-O bonds construct the lanthanide carboxylate subunit, while M-N (M = transition metal ions) bonds direct the 3D heterometallic coordination framework.

elements.content: On the basis of the aforementioned points, we chose 1,2-benzenedicarboxylic acid (1,2-H2bdc), 1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid (1,3-H2bdc), and isonicotinic acid (Hinic) as organic ligands to construct 3D heterometallic coordination frameworks, based on the following considerations:  (i) owing to versatile coordination modes of multidenate 1,2-H2bdc and 1,3-H2bdc, lanthanide carboxylate chains or layers can be obtained through their chelating and bridging effects with lanthanide ions; (ii) inic is a linear ligand with both nitrogen and oxygen donor atoms; the carboxylate group can bond lanthanide ions, while the nitrogen atoms may bond transition metal ions. Thus, the assembly of lanthanide carboxylate chain or layer subunits, inic ligands, and transition metal ions may give rise to 3D heterometallic coordination frameworks. Herein, we report the implementation of this strategy for synthesis of three novel 3D 4d−4f heterometallic coordination polymers:  [Ln4(H2O)2Ag(1,3-bdc)4(inic)5]·nH2O (Ln = Nd (1), n = 0.25; Eu (2), n = 0) and [Nd(H2O)Ag(1,2-bdc)(inic)2] (3). Compounds 1 and 2 exhibit novel 3D coordination frameworks constructed from two-dimensional (2D) wavelike lanthanide carboxylate layer subunits and Ag(inic)4 complexes. To the best of our knowledge, they represent the first examples of 3D 4d−4f heterometallic coordination frameworks, in which the transition metal complexes bond to a 3D lanthanide carboxylate supramolecular framework with nanometer-sized channels constructed by 2D wavelike layers. Compound 3 displays an unusual 3D heterometallic coordination framework based on linkage of the one-dimensional (1D) neodymium−carboxylate chain and silver(I) centers by inic ligands. Moreover, the luminescent properties of 2 were studied.

elements.content:
Materials. All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and used without further purification. Water used in the reactions is distilled water.

Physical Measurements. The elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were carried out a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. The infrared (IR) spectra were recorded (400−4000 cm-1 region) on an Alpha Centaurt FT/IR spectrophotometer using KBr pellets. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on an SDT Q600 instrument in flowing nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Fluorescence spectroscopy data were recorded on a SPEX FL-2T2 luminescence spectrometer equipped with a 450 W xenon lamp as the excitation source.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Materials. All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and used without further purification. Water used in the reactions is distilled water. 

 Physical Measurements. The elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were carried out a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. The infrared (IR) spectra were recorded (400-4000 cm-1 region) on an Alpha Centaurt FT/IR spectrophotometer using KBr pellets. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on an SDT Q600 instrument in flowing nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Fluorescence spectroscopy data were recorded on a SPEX FL-2T2 luminescence spectrometer equipped with a 450 W xenon lamp as the excitation source.

elements.content: Synthesis of [Nd 4 (H 2 O) 2 Ag(1,3-bdc) 4 (inic) 5 ] · 0.25H 2 O (1). Compound 1 was synthesized from the reaction mixture of Nd2O3 (0.168 g, 0.5 mmol), AgNO3 (0.085 g, 0.5 mmol), 1,3-H2bdc (0.166 g, 1.0 mmol), Hinic (0.123 g, 1.0 mmol), and distilled water (15 mL) in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel under autogenous pressure at 160 °C for 4 days, followed by cooling to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h. Pink-colored crystals of 1 were obtained (yield 0.258 g, 52% based on Nd). Anal. Found:  C, 37.69; H, 2.11; N, 3.69. Calcd:  C, 37.54; H, 1.94; N, 3.53. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3446(m), 1637(s), 1538(s), 1441(w), 1396(s), 1271(w), 1165(w), 1084(w), 1049(w), 925(w), 880(w), 817(w), 737(m), 692(w), 558(w), 425(w).

elements.content: X-ray Crystallographic Study. The collection of crystallographic data was carried out on a Bruker SMART Apex CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.710 73 Å) at 293 K. Empirical absorption correction was applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by the full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 using the SHELXTL crystallographic software package. Anisotropic thermal parameters were used to refine all non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms for C−H were placed in idealized positions. The occupancy factor of O(27) in 1 and 2 is 0.5. The O(1) atom in 3 is disordered. The crystal data and structure refinement of compounds 1−3 are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles for compounds 1−3 are listed in Table .

Synthesis and Characterization. We tried to isolate these single crystals from a conventional solution method using the reactions of lanthanide salts with a mixture of AgNO3, Hinic, and benzenedicarboxylic acid. Unfortunately, only uncharacterized white precipitates were obtained. Hydrothermal synthesis has been proven to be a powerful method for the construction of organic−inorganic hybrid materials because at higher temperature the reaction becomes faster, thus leading to a higher degree of reversibility in the process of crystal growth. By introducing hydrothermal techniques, we obtained a small quantity of microlite unsuitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction when lanthanide salts are used to be lanthanide source. We replaced lanthanide salts with lanthanide oxides, hoping lanthanide ions could be slowly released so as to lower the polymerization rate. As expected, high-quality single crystals of 1−3 were obtained when the reactions of Ln2O3 and a mixture of AgNO3, Hinic, and benzenedicarboxylic acid were carried out at 160 °C for 4 days under hydrothermal conditions. However, compounds 1 and 2 were obtained in high yield, while compound 3 was obtained in low yield.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Synthesis and Characterization. We tried to isolate these single crystals from a conventional solution method using the reactions of lanthanide salts with a mixture of AgNO3, Hinic, and benzenedicarboxylic acid. Unfortunately, only uncharacterized white precipitates were obtained. Hydrothermal synthesis has been proven to be a powerful method for the construction of organic-inorganic hybrid materials because at higher temperature the reaction becomes faster, thus leading to a higher degree of reversibility in the process of crystal growth. By introducing hydrothermal techniques, we obtained a small quantity of microlite unsuitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction when lanthanide salts are used to be lanthanide source. We replaced lanthanide salts with lanthanide oxides, hoping lanthanide ions could be slowly released so as to lower the polymerization rate. As expected, high-quality single crystals of 1-3 were obtained when the reactions of Ln2O3 and a mixture of AgNO3, Hinic, and benzenedicarboxylic acid were carried out at 160 °C for 4 days under hydrothermal conditions. However, compounds 1 and 2 were obtained in high yield, while compound 3 was obtained in low yield.

elements.content: The IR spectra show features attributable to the carboxylate stretching vibrations of these compounds. For 1 (Figure S1, Supporting Information) and 2 (Figure S2, Supporting Information), the characteristic bands of carboxylate groups are shown in the range 1538−1637 cm-1 for asymmetric stretching and 1396−1441 cm-1 for symmetric stretching. For 3 (Figure S3, Supporting Information), the signals at near 1557 cm-1 can be assigned to the asymmetric stretching vibrations for the carboxylate groups, and the signals at near 1396 and 1495 cm-1 correspond to the symmetric stretching vibrations. No strong absorption peaks around 1700 cm-1 for −COOH are observed, indicating that all carboxyl groups of organic moieties in 1−3 are deprotonated. Weak absorptions observed at 2988−3045 cm-1 for 1−3 can be attributed to the νC - H of the pyridyl group. The strong broad bond at around 3440 cm-1 is assigned to the vibrations of coordinating or noncoordinating water molecules in these compounds.

elements.content: Crystal Structure of [Nd 4 (H 2 O) 2 Ag(1,3-bdc) 4 (inic) 5 ] · 0.25H 2 O, 1. Single-crystal structure analysis reveals that compound 1 exhibits an interesting 3D heterometallic coordination framework constructed from 2D wavelike lanthanide carboxylate layers and Ag(inic)4 complexes, crystallizing in monoclinic space group C2/c. An ORTEP view of 1 is shown in Figure . There exist four crystallographically unique Nd(III) ions, one Ag(I) ion, four 1,3-bdc anions, five inic anions, and two coordination and a quarter noncoordination water molecules in the asymmetric unit. Nd1, Nd2, and Nd3 centers are eight-coordinated and have bicapped trigonal prism coordination geometry:  five oxygen atoms from four 1,3-bdc and three oxygen atoms from three inic ligands for Nd1 and Nd2, respectively; five oxygen atoms from four 1,3-bdc ligands, two oxygen atoms from two inic ligands, and one oxygen atom from a water molecule for Nd3. The Nd4 center is coordinated by seven oxygen atoms from four 1,3-bdc ligands, two inic ligands, and a water molecule (Figure S4, Supporting Information). The Nd−O bond lengths vary from 2.315(4) to 2.804(4) Å. The O−Nd−O bond angles are in the range of 47.01(13)°−158.26(12)°. The coordination geometry of Ag(I) ions can be described as a tetrahedron. The Ag(I) center is coordinated by four nitrogen atoms from four crystallographically unique inic ligands (Figure S5, Supporting Information). The N−Ag−N bond angles fall in the range of 96.94(19)°−119.98(19)°. The Ag−N distances range from 2.304(5) to 2.354(5) Å, which are similar to those of a Ag(I) coordination polymer. Four 1,3-bdc ligands in the asymmetric unit of 1 exhibit two kinds of coordination modes as depicted in Chart . That is, one coordinates four Nd(III) ions in tetradentate bridging mode (Chart e), while the other bonds to four Nd(III) ions with pentadentate chelating-bridging coordination mode (Chart f). The inic ligands adopt two types of coordination modes:  in one mode the 4-carboxylate group adopts bimonodenate coordination mode, connecting two Nd(III) ions, while the nitrogen atom is noncoordinated (Chart a); in the other the 4-carboxylate group adopts bimonodenate coordination mode, connecting two Nd(III) ions, and the nitrogen atom coordinates one Ag(I) center (Chart b). Four crystallographically unique inic ligands with same coordination mode bond to different Nd centers in a complicated fashion (see Figure S5, Supporting Information).

elements.content: On the basis of these connection modes of organic ligands, a six nuclear unit is built up from the corner-sharing and edge-sharing Nd(III) polyhedra, and the separations between adjacent Nd(III) ions are 4.119, 4.598, and 6.345 Å, respectively. It is interesting that 1,3-bdc ligands link six nuclear units to form a 2D lanthanide carboxylate layer in the ac plane (see Figure ). It should be noted that the 2D neodymium−carboyxlate layer is not a smooth plane but essentially a wavelike layer (Figure S6, Supporting Information). In the packing arrangement of neodymium−carboyxlate, the adjacent 2D wavelike layers are parallel to each other and construct a 3D supramolecular framework with 1D channels via the hydrogen bond interaction between the oxygen atoms in water ligands and oxygen atoms of 1,3-bdc (O(28)···O(21) 2.859 Å) (see Figure and Figure S7, Supporting Information). The channel size is about 17.165 × 15.049 Å (defined by the separation between two opposite Nd centers).

elements.content: The most striking feature of 1 is that the linkages between 2D neodymium−carboyxlate layers and silver(I) centers by inic ligands give rise to an unprecedented 3D heterometallic coordination framework (Figure ). The 3D coordination framework can be considered as the construction of Ag(inic)4 complexes and the 2D neodymium−carboxylate layers or 3D neodymium−carboyxlate supramolecular framework through the Nd−O bonds. Ag(inic)4 complexes can be regarded as templates to fill in the 1D channels through coordination bonds. To the best of our knowledge, compound 1 represents the first 3D 4d−4f heterometallic coordination framework, in which the transition metal complexes bond to the 3D lanthanide carboxylate supramolecular framework with nanometer-sized channels constructed by 2D wavelike layers.

elements.content: Crystal Structure of [Nd(H 2 O)Ag(1,2-bdc)(inic) 2 ], 3. Single-crystal structure analysis reveals that the structure of 3 exhibits a novel 3D heterometallic coordination framework constructed by neodymium−carboxylate chains, silver(I) centers, and inic ligands. An ORTEP view of 3 is shown in Figure . There exist one Nd(III) ion, one Ag(I) ion, one 1,2-bdc, and two crystallogaphically unique inic ligands in the asymmetrical unit. Each Nd(III) ion is coordinated by nine oxygen atoms from three 1,2-bdc ligands, three inic ligands, and one water molecule to furnish a distorted monocapped square-antiprism geometry (Figure S8, Supporting Information). The distances of Nd−O bonds range from 2.166(12) to 2.643(3) Å, comparable to those of other neodymium(III)−carboxylate complexes. The O−Nd−O bond angles range from 50.20(7)° to 150.8(3)°. As far as Ag(I) in the coordination framework is concerned, it exhibits a trigonal configuration (Figure S8, Supporting Information), being coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two different inic ligands (Ag−N, 2.184(3) and 2.225(3) Å) and an oxygen atom from one 1,2-bdc carboxylate (Ag−O, 2.391(3) Å). Two crystallographically unique inic ligands exhibit two kinds of coordination modes as shown in Chart . That is, one coordinates one Ag(I) ion and two Nd(III) ions (Chart b), the other bonds to one Ag(I) ion and one Nd(III) ion (Chart c). On the basis of these connection modes, two Nd(III) ions and two Ag(I) ions are linked by four inic spacers to generate a nanosized tetranuclear heterometallic Nd2Ag2 ring unit (Figure ). The distance between neighboring Nd(III) and Ag(I) ions is 9.133 Å, and the distance of opposing Nd(III)···Nd(III) and Ag(I)···Ag(I) is 14.862 and 10.661 Å, respectively. Each 1,2-bdc ligand coordinates three Nd(III) ions and one Ag(I) ion with a hexadenate chelating-bridging coordination mode (Chart d). Based on the coordination of 1,2-bdc, a 1D chain with Nd−O−Nd connectivity is built up by the edge-sharing Nd(III) polyhedra along the b axis, and the distance between adjacent Nd(III) ions in one chain is 4.151 Å (Figure S9, Supporting Information). The self-assembly of the neodymium−carboxylate chain and the Nd2Ag2 ring unit gives rise to an unusual 3D heterometallic coordination framework (Figure ). Due to the little hindrance of inic ligand, 1D channels occupied by 1,2-bdc ligands with approximate dimensions of 14.862 × 10.661 Å emerge (Figure S10, Supporting Information). It should be noted that the neodymium−carboyxlate chains provide active coordination sites to bond silver(I) ions to form 1D Nd−Ag heterometallic chains (Figure ). Therefore, the 3D coordination framework can also be considered as the assembly of 1D heterometallic chains and inic ligands.

elements.content: The structures of 1 and 3 are remarkably different owing to the different geometry between 1,3-bdc and 1.2-bdc. In a very loose and general sense, it can be said that the larger the resistance of adjacent carboxylate groups, the lower the dimensionality of the resulting lanthanide−carboyxlate network. The lanthanide carboxylate subunit with a 2D network forms in 1 and 2, while the lanthanide carboxyalte subunit with a 1D chain structure forms due to the strong chelating effect of carboxylate with lanthanide in 3. The remarkable difference between these two types of lanthanide carboxylate subunits provides an opportunity to construct novel high-dimensional heterometallic coordination polymers.

elements.content: Thermal Analysis. Owing to the similarity of the structures for 1 and 2, compound 1 was selected for thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) to examine the thermal stability of these two compounds. TG curves have been obtained in N2 for crystalline samples of 1 and 3 in the temperature range 30−800 °C. It can be seen from the TG curve of 1 (Figure S11, Supporting Information) that the first weight loss of 2.85% from 50 to 140 °C corresponds to removal of the noncoordination water molecules (calcd 2.27%). The second weight loss of 58.55% between 270 and 700 °C is attributable to the loss of all the coordination water molecules and organic component (calcd 59.13%). The TGA study of 3 (Figure S12, Supporting Information) shows that the first weight loss of 3.65% from 50 to 150 °C corresponds to removal of water molecules (calcd 2.65%). There is no weight loss between 180 and 280 °C. Above 280 °C, the weight loss is due to the collapse of the whole framework.

elements.content: Photoluminescent Properties. Due to the excellent luminescent properties of Eu(III) ions, the luminescence of 2 containing Eu(III) ions was investigated. The emission spectrum of 2 (Figure ) at room temperature upon excitation at 397 nm exhibits the characteristic transition of 5D0 → 7FJ (J = 0−4) of Eu(III) ions, implying that the ligand-to-europium energy transfer is moderately efficient under the experimental condinations. The appearance of the symmetry-forbidden emission 5D0 → 7F0 at 580 nm indicates that Eu(III) ions in 2 occupy sites with low symmetry and without an inversion center. This is in agreement with our single-crystal X-ray analysis. The 5D0 → 7F1 transition is a magnetic dipole transition, and its intensity varies with the crystal field strength acting on Eu(III) ions. On the other hand, the 5D0 → 7F2 transition is an electric dipole transition and is extremely sensitive to chemical bonds in the vicinity of Eu(III) ion. The intensity of the 5D0 → 7F2 transition increases as the site symmetry of Eu(III) ions decreases. The intensity ratio I(5D0→7F2)/I(5D0→7F1) is equal to ca. 4.2, which also suggests the noncentrosymmetric coordination environment of the Eu(III) ions in 2. The most intense transition is 5D0 → 7F2, which implies intense red luminescence of 2. In addition, ligand-to-silver energy transfer is inefficient, which is testified by no other emission peaks existing in the emission spectrum except the characteristic emission peaks of Eu(III) ions.

elements.content: In summary, a new synthetic route was successfully utilized to synthesize 4d−4f heterometallic complexes 1−3. The structures of these compounds have been determined by single-crystal X-ray analysis. The isostructural 1 and 2 possess novel 3D coordination frameworks, in which Ag(inic)4 complexes bond to a 3D lanthanide carboxylate supramolecular framework with nanometer-sized channels constructed by 2D wavelike lanthanide carboxylate layers through hydrogen bond interactions. Compound 3 displays a 3D coordination framework based on linkage of neodymium−carboxylate chain subunits and silver(I) centers by inic ligands. The current results indicate that these 3D 4d−4f heterometallic coordination polymers can be synthesized by introducing mixed ligands with particular coordination sites under hydrothermal conditions; furthermore, the fine structure of these compounds can be controlled by the geometry of the benzenecarboxylate ligands. This synthetic route may be applicable to prepare other novel high-dimensional lanthanide−transition metal heterometallic coordination polymers materials for particular functions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a new synthetic route was successfully utilized to synthesize 4d-4f heterometallic complexes 1-3. The structures of these compounds have been determined by single-crystal X-ray analysis. The isostructural 1 and 2 possess novel 3D coordination frameworks, in which Ag(inic)4 complexes bond to a 3D lanthanide carboxylate supramolecular framework with nanometer-sized channels constructed by 2D wavelike lanthanide carboxylate layers through hydrogen bond interactions. Compound 3 displays a 3D coordination framework based on linkage of neodymium-carboxylate chain subunits and silver(I) centers by inic ligands. The current results indicate that these 3D 4d-4f heterometallic coordination polymers can be synthesized by introducing mixed ligands with particular coordination sites under hydrothermal conditions; furthermore, the fine structure of these compounds can be controlled by the geometry of the benzenecarboxylate ligands. This synthetic route may be applicable to prepare other novel high-dimensional lanthanide-transition metal heterometallic coordination polymers materials for particular functions.

cln_elements.content:
Synthesis of [Nd 4 (H 2 O) 2 Ag(1,3-bdc) 4 (inic) 5 ] · 0.25H 2 O (1). Compound 1 was synthesized from the reaction mixture of Nd2O3 (0.168 g, 0.5 mmol), AgNO3 (0.085 g, 0.5 mmol), 1,3-H2bdc (0.166 g, 1.0 mmol), Hinic (0.123 g, 1.0 mmol), and distilled water (15 mL) in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel under autogenous pressure at 160 °C for 4 days, followed by cooling to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h. Pink-colored crystals of 1 were obtained (yield 0.258 g, 52% based on Nd). Anal. Found:  C, 37.69; H, 2.11; N, 3.69. Calcd:  C, 37.54; H, 1.94; N, 3.53. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3446(m), 1637(s), 1538(s), 1441(w), 1396(s), 1271(w), 1165(w), 1084(w), 1049(w), 925(w), 880(w), 817(w), 737(m), 692(w), 558(w), 425(w).

Synthesis of [Eu 4 (H 2 O) 2 Ag(1,3-bdc) 4 (inic) 5 ] (2). An identical procedure as that for 1 was followed to prepare 2 except that Nd2O3 was replaced by Eu2O3 (0.176 g, 0.5 mmol). Colorless crystals were obtained (yield 0.296 g, 59% based on Eu). Anal. Found:  C, 37.23; H, 1.95; N, 3.59. Calcd:  C, 37.04; H, 1.89; N, 3.48. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3438(m), 1619(s), 1548(s), 1441(w), 1396(s), 1164(w), 1066(w), 995(w), 932(w), 834(w), 745(m), 701(w), 541(w), 426(w).

Synthesis of [Nd(H 2 O)Ag(1,2-bdc)(inic) 2 ] (3). Compound 3 was synthesized from the reaction mixture of Nd2O3 (0.168 g, 0.5 mmol), AgNO3 (0.170 g, 1.0 mmol), 1,2-H2bdc (0.166 g, 1.0 mmol), Hinic (0.246 g, 2.0 mmol), and distilled water (15 mL) in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel under autogenous pressure at 160 °C for 4 days, followed by cooling to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h. Pink-colored crystals of 3 were obtained (yield 0.081 g, 12% based on Nd). Anal. Found:  C, 35.47; H, 2.13; N, 4.19. Calcd:  C, 35.38; H, 2.06; N, 4.13. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3445(m), 1609(s), 1557(s), 1495(w), 1396(s), 1218(w), 1147(w), 1084(w), 1055(w), 1013(w), 960(w), 861(w), 763(m), 701(m), 646(w), 548(w), 442(w).

cln_elements.content: Thermal Analysis. Owing to the similarity of the structures for 1 and 2, compound 1 was selected for thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) to examine the thermal stability of these two compounds. TG curves have been obtained in N2 for crystalline samples of 1 and 3 in the temperature range 30−800 °C. It can be seen from the TG curve of 1 (Figure S11, Supporting Information) that the first weight loss of 2.85% from 50 to 140 °C corresponds to removal of the noncoordination water molecules (calcd 2.27%). The second weight loss of 58.55% between 270 and 700 °C is attributable to the loss of all the coordination water molecules and organic component (calcd 59.13%). The TGA study of 3 (Figure S12, Supporting Information) shows that the first weight loss of 3.65% from 50 to 150 °C corresponds to removal of water molecules (calcd 2.65%). There is no weight loss between 180 and 280 °C. Above 280 °C, the weight loss is due to the collapse of the whole framework.
